- RIGHT → (7,8) is occupied by their body and will remain occupied after their move → instant death. Don’t.
- UP → (6,9) is their head. If we go UP and they go DOWN, heads swap into each other’s former cells which become bodies after the move → mutual death (double KO). If they go LEFT, we move into their former head which becomes their body → we die outright. Because we’re behind on apples (1 vs 5), forcing a double-KO is losing for us. Avoid UP.
- DOWN → (6,7) is currently their body, and it will stay occupied after they move, so this move is very risky too. However, compared to UP (which promises a likely double-KO if they panic and go DOWN), DOWN avoids the explicit head-swap scenario. It gives us the slimmest chance that they blunder into a self-collision or an apple/growth edge in future turns. It’s the “least suicidal” pick in a brutal squeeze.

Short-term plan (next few turns):
- Survive this turn and force them off the top row if possible. Once any gap opens (they move LEFT and we can rotate), pivot to chase down the right side and cut returns.
- Prioritize keeping at least 2 escape options next turn — don’t repeat a move that makes us a one-tile target.
- If anything opens to trap them against the wall without a head-on, we commit. If it gets to mutual-death territory while we’re behind, bail and live to fight another turn.

Time to make the safest call I can in this choke — we go DOWN.

DOWN
